bboxes.raw_text:
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J.- Clay
Claiborne, aide to the Republican
National Committee, had his bail
continued here when he pleaded
not guilty to an indictment charg-
ing him with aiding and abetting
violators of the election laws.


The plea was entered before
Atlantic County Judge Paul M.
Salzburg who agreed to allow Cla-
borne to remain free on $4,000
bond. Claiborne was accused of
being responsible for printing
almost million and a half bro
chures urging citizens to write
in the name of the Rev. Martin
Luther King, Jr., in the last
presidential election.


"The pamphlets we're printed
to attempt to divide the Negro
vote and to slow down the cleo
tive procedure" it was charged
by New Jersey Attorney General
Arthur ]. Stills.

NEW YORK The National
Association for the Advancement
of Colored People has called
upon investment houses. banking
institutions, insurance compan-
les and pension funds "to de-
cline to participate" in bidding
on three Mississippi bond issues
totaling $32,650.0O0.


In a memorandum of Dec. ii
to so leading financial institu-
tions in New York City, RoyWil-
kins asked withholding of bids
from the following issues: Pearl
River Water Supply District.
$24, 100000 revenue refunding
bonds for bidding: and two school
bond issues, general obligation
of the state, totaling $4,000. 900
for bidding.


Leake and Scott counties, two
of the five in the Pearl River
Valley district. border Neshoba
County where three civil rights
workers were lynched last June
near Philadelphia, the county
seat.


MIR. wilkins memorandum cit
ed a resolution adopted by $500
delegates to the Association an
nual convention in Washington,
DC, last June. The resolution
urged action by the Association,
its branches and members to see
that "no bank or other financial
institution or public entity -.
seek, bid for, or buy bonds, notes
or other obligation of the State
of Mississippi or of its munich
palities."


1.-The brutal discrimination
visited by Mississippi upon its
Negro citizens requires no elab-
Grafton here" the memorandum
continued. "Nor does 1t need to
be documented that the money
raised by Mississippi borrowing
will be spent in discriminatory
manner"


The State of Mississippi. &C
cording to the state auditor, on
June 30, 1868, had bonded debt
of 1891 ,672,7l8 outstanding, in
Guiding obligations of its 81 coun-
ties and 262 municipalities.

NAACP


ASK BROKERS
TO IGNORE
MISSISSIPPI
investments

Phoenix Trotting Park w. Van
Buren, and Cotton Lane, has been
voted racing dates of March Is
20, 1865, on the Grand Circuit,
harness racings major league
road show.


This is the first time the Board
of Stewards of the Grand Circuit
have ever approved dates for
harness race track in its inaug-
ural season. Phoenix Trotting
Park opens its 60-night season
Jan. IL, 1865.


The Grand Circuit is the equiv
alent Of the world series in base
ball.


Phoenix Trotting Park will be
the second stop on the Grand
Circuit, in which the nation
top 2-year-old and 3-year-old
trotters and PAGERS compete.


The Grand Circuit was founded
in 1873 and includes in its dates
such famed races as The Ham
bletonian.

Commission Chairman JohnW.
Macy Jr., announcing the policy,
said the effective date was set
at July l. 1868, to allow agencies
which might be disqualified "a
reas enable opportunity to con-
slider a change in governing pol
icies."

WASHINGTON The Civil Ser
vice Commission said only chari-
table agencies that operate under
nondiscriminatory rules will be
allowed in the future to solicit
donations at federal offices or
military duty stations.

Members of the Board photographed the 5th annual


ov Convocaon of Church of God in Christ Memphis Tenn
Seated left to rights Bishop A. B. McEwen chairman Bishop OIL
1ones Senior Bishop Bishop j. o. Patterson General Secy
Standing right Bishops John White W. G. Shipman Z. E
Bennett S. M. Crouch o. M. Kelly BS Lyle Wyoming Wells
c. H. Brewer and L. H. Ford

Mrs. James Boozer, $3.50 E. Superior Ave.
18th wedding anniversary cake Festivities held
Eks Lodge 1907 South Seventh Ave., Friday night


married in Arkansas and they have
n Arizona since 1915.


daughter. Photo Bobby Heard
